page.title: 07Waterways on Horse-Eye Level
page.content: The ecology of Horse-Eye Level has altered to a degree due to some farmers who grub out the hedgerows with the consequent loss of natural habitat of local wildlife, especially the partridge. There is a lot of marsh flora on Horse-Eye Level. A common sight is the Canadian Duckpond Weed introduced to the waterways during the Second World War. This prevented the enemy planes from using the waterways for navigational purposes. The dykes are important for their rich variety of submerged aquatic and emergent plant species such as Common Duckweed (Lemna Minor), Bur Reed (Sparganium Erectum), Bullrush (Typha Augustifolia), Reeds (Phragmites Communis), Rushes, Iris, Ragwort, Reedmace, Knapweed. Odd trees that live in theis area include Elderberry, Hawthorn, Blackthorn, Oaks & Willows.
